newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel says spy suspect treated well in Egypt jail.
newsitem.headline: Israel says spy suspect treated well in Egypt jail.

text.p: An Israeli detained in Egypt on suspicion of spying for the Jewish state is being treated well in prison, Israel's Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.

"Israeli consul in Cairo Yehoshua Gabbai met Israeli citizen Azam Azam at his place of detention in Cairo," the ministry said in a statement. "Gabbai reported to the Foreign Ministry that Azam Azam is well and that he said during the meeting that he is receiving good treatment and suitable conditions."
Azam, 35, chief mechanic at an Israeli-owned textile factory in Egypt, was arrested in Cairo last week by security authorities along with Egyptian national Emad eddin Abdel Hamid.
Egyptian security sources have said Hamid confessed to spying for Israel and receiving espionage equipment. Israel has insisted Azam, of Arab origin, was innocent and demanded his release.
Egypt will this week issue an official charge sheet detailing accusations against the two men, an Egyptian public prosecution source said.
The source said Azam could have the lawyers he requested. Israel said it would continue to take any action that could assist Azam.
Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said on Friday Israeli leaders had squandered the chance to secure Azam's release through quiet diplomacy by making the affair public.
Egypt in 1979 became the first Arab state to sign a peace treaty with Israel but relations have cooled sharply since right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June.
